refnamediv.refpurpose: execute a SQL statement on a remote DSN

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function can be used to execute SQL on a remote data source directly.

The result_set parameter is useful for obtaining a result-set quickly and easily. However, if the result-set is going to be large, this comes at a cost in terms of time and resources, particularly memory, since Virtuoso will have to obtain all results from the statement and build the result-set arrays in memory before returning back to the caller.
A more efficient way is to obtain a cursor handle and iterate through the result set one row at a time:

simplelist.member: Use rexecute() to get the cursor handle.
Iterate over the results with rnext()
If rmoreresults() does not return an error or SQL_NO_DATA_FOUND continue the loop with rnext(), otherwise

refsect1.para: To keep Virtuoso from obtaining the whole result set from the remote, pass NULL as the result_set parameter when calling rexecute.

Rexecute() supports IN parameters and can also support INOUT and OUT parameters. If INOUT and OUT parameters are to be used then cursors should not be used with this function (as the values of output parameters in ODBC are not guaranteed to be set before SQLMoreResults() returns SQL_NO_DATA_FOUND). Rexecute supports INOUT and OUT parameters by extending the in_params vector and requiring it to be a PL variable so values can be set back to it.

Unless explicitly granted, only the DBA group is permitted to use the rexecute() to maintain security. Caution is required here since any user granted use of rexecute() has full control of the remote data source set-up by the DBA, however limited to the overall abilities of the remote user on the remote data source. Users can be granted and denied access to this function using the following commands:
refsect1.programlisting: GRANT REXECUTE ON '<attached_dsn_name>' TO <user_name> REVOKE REXECUTE ON '<attached_dsn_name>' FROM <user_name>

note.title: Note:
note.para: rstmtexec() provides a short-hand to this function.

refsect2.title: dsn
refsect2.para: The data source where the SQL statement should be executed. You must make sure that you have already defined the data source using the vd_remote_data_source function or by attaching tables from it.

refsect2.title: sql_state
refsect2.para: A varchar containing the SQL State returned from the remote data source.

refsect2.title: error_message
refsect2.para: A varchar containing any error message returned from the remote.

refsect2.title: in_params
refsect2.para: A vector of parameters to the statement if the executed statement has parameters. IN input parameters are specified as literals whereas OUT and INOUT parameters are specified as vectors of 3 elements for OUT and 4 elements for INOUT as follows:

simplelist.member: [0] - the type of the parameter ('OUT' or 'INOUT')
[1] - the datatype that the parameter is bound to on the remote
[2] - the buffer length for the output parameter
[3] - (INOUT only) the input value of the parameter

refsect2.para: Non-vector parameters in the in_params parameter of rexecute are considered IN parameters, so the rexecute remains backwards compatible.

refsect2.title: num_cols
refsect2.para: Number of columns in the result set if the statement returned one.

refsect2.title: stmt_meta
refsect2.para: A vector containing result metadata, etc.

row.entry: An array containing description of each column in the result set (see table below for contents)
An integer 1 indicates that results are available.
Column type as an internal type code corresponding, but not equal to ODBC SQL type codes.

refsect2.title: result_set
refsect2.para: A vector of vectors containing each row in the result set.
